Award.AwardTitle: SUPPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON APPLIED AND THEORETICAL STATISTICS
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Committee on Applied and Theoretical Statistics (CATS) organizes studies and workshops that provide top-quality statistical science advice to help guide major government programs. Some of those programs support the statistical science community, but others do not yet have strong ties to it. CATS activities are carried out by specially appointed committees of experts tailored for each particular activity and in general survey existing research frontiers and recommend best steps for strengthening or applying them; review federal programs and recommend improvements; and/or provide strategic advice to federal programs that depend on the mathematical sciences community.

Overall, the mission of CATS is to manage and reduce uncertainty in national decision-making through the use of modern statistical thinking and to nurture a vibrant statistical sciences research enterprise. The latter goal calls for a statistical sciences discipline that is well-connected with other fields of science, engineering, and medicine; absorbs challenges from those other fields; and maintains a robust core. CATS works to strengthen these attributes of the community.

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public 

 

Award #1351163

SUPPORT FOR THE

COMMITTEE ON APPLIED AND THEORETICAL STATISTICS

Period of Performance: 07/15/2014–06/30/2017

 

The Committee on Applied and Theoretical Statistics (CATS) of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine provides expert advice on statistics and data analytics to federal agencies. That advice helps to guide federal investments and to incorporate statistical insight into public policy. CATS also informs the greater statistics community of emerging national challenges, thus helping the field to remain robust.

The subject award supported six meetings of CATS, three conference sessions (ENAR 2016 on improving scientific reproducibility, and JSM 2016 and USCOTS 2017 on data science education), and a public symposium on data-driven city planning and policy. It jointly supported (with the National Institutes of Health) a workshop on refining the concept of scientific inference when working with big data. CATS also initiated and/or oversaw additional projects that were funded separately, including the following:

  • A roundtable on data science postsecondary education (funded by the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, the National Institutes of Health, the National Academy of Sciences W.K. Kellogg Foundation Fund, the Association for Computing Machinery, and the American Statistical Association);
  • A study on strengthening data science methods for Department of Defense personnel and readiness missions (funded by DoD);
  • A study on envisioning the data science discipline from an undergraduate perspective (funded by NSF/DMS, NSF/CISE, and NSF/SBE);
  • A review of research proposals on statistical methodologies for assessing variables in eyewitness performance (funded by the Laura and John Arnold Foundation);
  • A workshop on statistical challenges in assessing and fostering the reproducibility of scientific results (funded by a previous NSF/DMS core support award but convened during this performance period); and
  • Two summary reports for workshops that convened prior to this performance period: Training Students to Extract Value from Big Data (funded by NSF/DMS and NSF/CISE) and Methods for Analyzing Images and Videos for Fisheries Stock Assessment (funded by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration).

 

The studies, workshops, and review each resulted in a published report, and each roundtable meeting is recorded, publicly webcast, and documented in a brief roundtable highlights.
